Award.AwardTitle: Mixing by Resonances in Multi-Scale Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop the theory of mixing by resonances in multi-scale systems in the presence of such phenomena as finite inertia, random fluctuations, and molecular diffusion. The constructed theory will provide an effective and accurate method to compute the size of the mixing domain in a given system, to estimate the rate, thoroughness, and uniformity of mixing, and to describe the appearance of coherent structures in a chaotic sea. The theory of processes on resonance surfaces will be combined with the adiabatic model of transport between those surfaces to develop a statistical long-term description of transport in systems with resonances. Numerical simulations and study of experimental data from microfluidics laboratory and space plasma experiments will be performed to identify the resonance mechanisms causing the transport of particles and describe the impact of additional stochastic processes on the stability of transport.

If successful, this work will result in the integration of often disconnected methods and techniques into a general transport theory for a wide class of flows, discrete maps, and Hamiltonian systems with resonances. One of the main components will be a novel technique to quantify different aspects of mixing and the persistence of quantitative characteristics in the presence of uncertainties and fluctuations in various multi-scale systems. The obtained results will have direct applications to a wide range of problems in science and engineering, such as microfluidics or other low Reynolds-number (microscale) flows, the transport of comets and asteroids through the solar system, energy exchange between excitation modes in condensed matter, and motion of charged particles in various electromagnetic fields of the Earth's magnetosphere or magnetic confinement fusion devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the current project was to develop the theory of mixing by resonances in multi-scale systems in the presence of such phenomena as finite inertia, random fluctuations, and molecular diffusion. The constructed theory yields an effective and accurate method to compute the size of the mixing domain in a given system, to estimate the rate, thoroughness, and uniformity of mixing, and to describe the appearance of coherent structures in a chaotic sea. For that purpose, the theory of resonance (singular) processes was combined with the adiabatic model of transport between those resonances to develop a statistical long-term description of transport in systems with resonances. Over the course of the project, we performed numerical simulations and study of experimental data from microfluidics laboratory and space plasma experiments. We identified the resonance mechanisms causing the transport of particles and described the impact of additional stochastic processes on the stability of transport.

One of the main outcomes of this work is the integration of often disconnected methods and techniques into a general transport theory for a wide class of fluid flows and Hamiltonian systems with resonances. One of the main components of this approach are: (a) a novel technique to quantify different aspects of mixing, and (b) clear indication of the persistence of quantitative characteristics in the presence of uncertainties and fluctuations in various multi-scale systems.

The obtained results have direct applications to a wide range of problems in science and engineering, such as microfluidics or other low Reynolds-number (microscale) flows, inluding biological flows, and motion of charged particles in various electromagnetic fields of the Earth's magnetosphere that drectly impacts Space Weather. Specifically, the main results of the project are:

(1) We showed that in the flows with small-but-nonzero Reynolds number under periodic actuation mixing is concentrated near the surfaces where the period of actuation matches the period of the unperturbed motion.

(2) We showed that effectiveness of transversal transport and mixing of chyme in the small intestine of humans, which is mainly due to the peristaltic contractions of the intestine walls, is very sensitive to the resonance between the period of the contractions and the internal period of vortices created in the flow. The obtained results can serve as an indication on the range of physiological parameters that yield acceptable range of flow properties.

(3) Dynamics of charged particles (ions and electrons) in the earth magnetosphere is to a large extend defined not only by the interaction of particles with a constant earth magnetic field, but also by their interaction with ever-changing electromagnetic waves. These phenomena can be described using the nonlinear theory of wave-particle resonance interaction. We showed that starting from the statistical distribution of waves' characteristics (obtain by the analysis of satellite data) we can accurately quantize the rate of acceleration of charged particles and predict of the transport of particles into the loss cone (drift in the pitch-angle), from which particles precipitate to the Earth.

The research program was tightly integrated with teaching and learning at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Include activities aimed at increased participation of undergraduate and graduate students in research, development Senior Design projects at Temple University and Co-Op projects at Drexel University. The results of the research were broadly disseminated through journal publications, technical presentations at scientific and engineering meetings and conferences, colloquia, and seminars at academic institutions.
